title: Overworked vet accidentally killed herself after cocktail of drink and drugs
text:
Louise O’Dwyer, an internationally renowned vet, died after falling asleep in the bath (Picture: Cavendish)

An overworked vet died when she fell asleep in the bath after taking sleeping tablets and drinking wine and gin, an inquest heard.

Louise O’Dwyer, 45, who had given lectures across the world, was suffering from a severe bout of ‘burnout’ through work commitments.

Ms O’Dwyer, from Wigan, Greater Manchester, had taken the pills and other medication as a ‘coping mechanism’ when she fell asleep.

Her partner found her submerged under the water when he went to check on her on May 5, 2019.

Tests showed Mrs O’Dwyer had traces of fluoxetine, paracetamol, beta blockers, amitriptyline, zopiclone, citallipram and propanol in her system and would have been more than twice the alcohol limit for driving.

The inquest into the death of Louise O’Dwyer heard she was suffering from a severe case of burnout with work (Picture: Cavendish)

Ms O’Dwer’s partner Paul Rogerson told the inquest in Bolton that she had some ‘insecurities’ and was forced to put her Masters on hold.

He said: ‘Louise never spoke to me about her panic attack but she became depressed and had problems sleeping.

‘In the short period of time leading up to her death she was having regular baths as she said it helped her to better deal with the side effects of the drugs as she was suffering so badly.

‘She was complaining of nausea, dizziness and drowsiness and she said taking more baths relaxed the side effects.

‘Louise was drinking and she liked to have a drink in the bath.’

Her sister Alison Bradshaw said she began suffering from anxiety and depression when she lost a lot of weight four years ago.

Louise O’Dwyer was a famous veterinary nurse who gave lectures around the world (Picture: Cavendish)

The inquest heard that Ms O’Dwyer, who had written 45 practical guide books, was referred to counselling after suffering a panic attack at a conference.

However she saw herself as a ‘perfectionist’ who had to perform ‘at her best all the time’.

Recording a verdict of death by misadventure Coroner Alan Walsh said: ‘From such a talented young lady to go into what may be said a meltdown in a short period of time is unimaginable.

‘But I want to make it clear.

‘This is not an alcoholic situation, it was more of a coping mechanism.

“She was very intelligent, both academically and practically.

‘She was an author of critical care and intensive care in veterinary science.

‘She was world renowned for her achievements and her ability to teach and lecture.’

He added: ‘She was suffering from burn out as a result of her overcommitment to others.

‘I don’t know how she honoured all those commitments and held down a job.

‘I believe she took the medication to try and help her to cope.

‘She needed to relax and by having the bath she became drowsy and had gone to sleep, and died from the immersion in the water.

‘She did not intend to end her life.’
description: Louise O'Dwyer, 45, was suffering from a severe bout of 'burnout' through work commitments.
